This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Kingsburg Fruit Packing has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Kingsburg Fruit Packing, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Kingsburg Fruit Packing has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

North & Middle Systems        Anhydrous Ammonia                45,000

South System                  Anhydrous Ammonia                 9,200



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prep

ared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Kingsburg Fruit Packing operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of fruit in Kingsburg, CA. The facility has two ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1 - North & Middle Systems

(12) Cold Storage Rooms

(2) Precool Rooms

(3) Fumigation Rooms (Used as Precoolers)

(4) CA Rooms (Used as Storage Rooms) 

(2) Hydrocoolers



Process 2 - South System

(2) Cold Storage Rooms

(1) Precool Room

(4) CA Rooms (Used as Storage Rooms)



1.2.2 Facility Location



Kingsburg Fruit Packing is located at 10363 Davis Ave, Kingsburg, CA 93631. The latitude and longitude of the four (4) high pressure receivers are: 

P1 High Pressure Receiver 1: 36.465835, -119.610116 

P1 High Pressure Receiver 2: 36.465837, -119.610103 

P1 High Pressure Receiver 3: 36.465917, -119.610119 

P2 High Pressure Receiver: 36.464578, -119.610150 



The facility is located approximately 5 miles west of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agricultural land.



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Kingsburg Fruit Packing is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Kingsburg Fruit Packing has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentiall

y minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Processes



The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



Control valve groups are located on the Process 1 roof, and other various locations. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the three (3) machinery rooms. 



Process Chemistry

The refrigeration system employed at Kingsburg Fruit Packing is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers & thermosyphon vessels and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. Each high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulator

The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and va

por ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Direct Expansion)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the high pressure receiver. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the main suction accumulator.



Hydrocooler

The purpose of the hydrocooler is to remove heat from water which is used to precool fresh fruit. The hydrocooler receives liquid from the flooded accumulator. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits th

e hydrocooler and is returned to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the hydrocooler contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Suction Accumulators

The purpose of the main suction accumulators is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulators receive vapor from the flooded accumulators and separate any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulators drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessels. Each main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulators contain low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Vessels

The purpose of the liquid transfer vessels is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receiver. The liquid transfer vessels receive liquid from the main suction accumulators. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessels reach the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessels can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulators and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the com

pressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers and the thermosyphon vessels. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to both the high pressure receivers and thermosyphon vessels. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Thermosyphon Vessels

The purpose of the thermosyphon vessels is to provide a supply of liquid ammonia necessary to cool the oil in the compressors. The thermosyphon vessels receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and supply high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon oil cooler on each screw compressor. Excess liquid in the thermosyphon vessels is piped to the high pressure receivers. High pressure ammonia vapor formed in each oil cooler is returned to the thermosyphon vessels. Under normal conditions, the thermosyphon vessels contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Coolers

The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through it. The oil coolers receive liquid from the thermosyphon vessels. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil cooler and is returned to the thermosyphon vessels. Under normal conditions, the oil cooler contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection System

The North Machinery room is equipped with an ammonia detector. A Cool Air LBW 50 provides low concentration detection and alerts personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm. Audible/visual alarms are available outside

and inside the machinery room. If the concentration reaches 150 ppm, the emergency ventilation system will be activated. 



Each sample system is equipped with an ammonia detector, vacuum pump, and tubing which extends to the rooms where air is sampled. The vacuum pump is used to draw air through the tubing into the detector. On two minute intervals, the system toggles from one sample point to the next. The sample systems provide ammonia detection to non-machinery rooms as is listed in the above table.



If the sample system detects an ammonia concentration exceeding 25 ppm, the system will activate a visible and audible alarm and notify plant personnel of the situation through the auto-dialer.



Fumigation Rooms 1-3 are all equipped with a Drager, Polytron TX ammonia detector which will sound an audible alarm if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm.



Emergency Control Box

Each machinery room is equipped with an Emergency Control Box (ECB). The ECBs are installed outside each machinery room and each one contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. 



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;

For Process 1, all relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates in

to the ammonia diffusion tank; 

For Process 2, all relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates to atmosphere, 7.25 ft above the roof;



Diffusion Tank

Process 1 refrigeration system is equipped with two ammonia diffusion tanks which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tank. The larger ammonia diffusion tank is 13'-5" dia. x 30' high (32,120 gallon capacity). At a water level of 15'-0", the tank contains 16,060 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.



Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint. Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Rec

iprocating Compressor Safety Devices

Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switch

Each main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The high pressure receivers for Process 1 and Process 2 are equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)

Each machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside each machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency by either using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass or by opening the Emergency 

Control Box.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Kingsburg Fruit Packing has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-cas

e and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration processes at the Kingsburg Fruit Packing facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration processes and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Kingsburg Fruit Packing has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Kingsburg Fruit Packing's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?

68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Kingsburg Fruit Packing has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Kingsburg Fruit Packing continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Kingsburg Fruit Packing's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Kingsburg Fruit Packing's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Kingsburg Fruit Packing has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing

PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Kingsburg Fruit Packing has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Kingsburg Fruit Packing now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Kingsburg Fruit Packing employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Kingsburg Fruit Packing will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
